thread.title_full: Nation magazine editor refers to John McCain, a Vietnam POW, as an 'armchair warrior' | Washington Examiner

author: T. Becket Adams
title: Nation magazine editor refers to John McCain, a Vietnam POW, as an 'armchair warrior'
text:
A magazine editor who has spent her entire professional career in newsrooms referred to former U.S. Navy pilot and POW Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., Wednesday as an "armchair warrior."
The Nation's Katrina vanden Heuvel wasn't born when the Arizona lawmaker began his career in the U.S. Navy. She was only eight-years-old when he was shot down near Hanoi and captured by the Vietnamese People's Army.
McCain has raised the alarm recently about Russia's alleged meddling in the 2016 presidential election.
Russian hackers broke into the private email accounts of Democratic National Committee staffers and Hillary Clinton 's campaign chairman, John Podesta. The hacking group WikiLeaks then published the electronic communications in installments during the presidential election.
McCain sees the hacks as a big deal. Some, including the Nation's editor and publisher, disagree.
"Will this set Armchair Warrior McCain straight?" vanden Heuvel asked Wednesday on social media as she shared a Washington Post story titled, "Russia's apparent meddling in U.S. election is not an act of war, cyber expert says."
The Post report quotes Michael Schmitt, chairman of the U.S. Naval War College's International Law Department, as saying the cyber attacks don't quite constitute an act of war.
"I'm no friend of the Russians," Schmitt told the paper. But the hacks are "not an initiation of armed conflict. It's not a violation of the U.N. Charter's prohibition on the use of force. It's not a situation that would allow the U.S. to respond in self-defense militarily."

By Anna Giaritelli • 02/08/17 4:53 PM McCain's service in the U.S. Navy began in 1958. He made his way eventually to aviation, and he flew as a pilot during the Vietnam War.
The 31-year-old Naval officer was shot down near Hanoi on Oct. 26, 1967, his aircraft brought down by the North Vietnamese Air Command's 61 st Battalion.
It was McCain's twenty-third mission.
Struggling to regain consciousness, and discovering that he had fractures in both arms and his right leg, the Navy pilot was soon captured by North Vietnamese forces. He was beaten and bayoneted as they stripped him of his clothes.
McCain was then taken to a so-called hospital where he was subjected repeatedly to brutal interrogations and beatings. His captors did not treat his wounds and broken body properly, the effects of which are evident to this day .

By Joseph Lawler • 02/08/17 4:45 PM McCain spent the following five years being transferred from one POW camp to the next. He was put in solitary confinement, beaten, used for propaganda purposes and repeatedly tortured.
McCain didn't regain his freedom until March 17, 1973.
Vanden Heuvel, for her part, graduated from Princeton University in 1981 . She worked at ABC News for the next two years . She joined the Nation in 1984 as a foreign affairs assistant editor. She was promoted five years later to editor-at-large.
She serves now as the Nation's editor and publisher, and she writes the occasional op-ed for the Post, the New York Times and the Boston Globe.
Vanden Heuvel also once interned for National Lampoon magazine.
